content:
There is an error in the Referee! Otherwise very nice problem to solve. UI too simple for my taste, but this game shouldn't be graphical masterpiece so I'll allow it :D

Now the issue:
Referee allows me to make a loop without any starting tile!
"Small 5" testcase accepts this (python) solution.
print("0 0 1 0 e")
print("0 0 0 1 e")
print("4 0 4 1 a")
print("1 1 2 1 3")
print("2 1 3 1 3")
print("4 1 4 2 a")
print("4 2 4 3 a")
print("3 3 4 3 a")
print("0 4 1 4 7")
print("0 3 0 4 7")
print("1 4 2 4 7")
print("2 4 3 4 7")
print("1 0 2 0 e")
print("2 0 3 0 e")
print("1 1 1 2 3")
print("3 1 3 2 3")
print("2 2 3 2 3")
print("0 2 0 3 7")
print("1 2 2 2 3")
print("1 3 2 3 3")

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is well designed and fun, with many test and validators of progressive difficulty. Thanks

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is well scrubbed and solid. The test cases are well structured and the instructions are easy to follow. I am generating all possible paths between each set of endpoints and then finding a combination that works to cover the entire board. This fairly brute force approach requires bare minimum optimizations to solve all test cases and validators, which I believe keeps it a legitimate medium puzzle.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Another great solo game by  Harry.B.
Statement is clear & easy to understand and there are lots of tests/validators to cover everything.

- Complete test case rehaul (Small, Medium, Large, Segmented)
- Visual updates: More visible checkpoints, blockers, directional tiles
- Slightly altered error messages

Ok also for Medium 1 Validator.
All should be ok now.
Ready to go.

Ok for all, except for Medium 1 Validator.
Still searching a solution.
Get:
1/1
Sortie standard :
0 0 0 0 c
Informations :
Same tile or not straight line provided.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Hi,

Is there currently an issue with the checkpoints being given?
For example for "Simple Test" the checkpoint at 0;2 is given as being for color '0' in the input but on the visual the flag & debug info indicate that it belongs to color 'e'.
In 'Small 3' at 3;2 it should be 'b' instead of 1.
In 'Medium 1' at 1;2 it should be 'e' instead of 4.
In 'Medium 3' at 0;0 it should be 'b' instead of 1.
In 'Simple Test (Validator)' at 2;0 it should be 'e' instead of 0.
In 'Small 3 Validator (Validator)' at 3;2 it should be 'b' instead of 'X'
In 'Small 3 Validator (Validator)' at 2;3 it should be 'e' instead of 'X'
In 'Medium 1 Validator (Validator)' at 4;5 it should be 'e' instead of '.'
In 'Medium 3 Validator (Validator)' at 6;1 it should be 'b' instead of 'c'

(Note: Unless otherwise specified, the comments below apply to Part 1 only.)

The Goal
* (Part 2) Briefly reference Part 1, including making it clear that special tiles from Part 1 are not used. (Similarly, when introducing Part 3, you could start by noting that the rules are the same as in Part 2, except for the additions, e.g. breakable blockers and tunnels.)

* (Part 2) Please add a placeholder for the link to Part 1 (and likewise a link to Part 2 for Part 3), and update them once the links are available.

Rules
* (Both Part 1 and Part 2) Please change "and or" to "and/or".

Input
* Next k Lines: Please change "string" to "integers". (I guess c may be an integer or a character in Part 3 only?)

* The presentation works well for Part 2 because the italicised explanation immediately follows the corresponding line description, making the section easy to follow. However, in Part 1 the italicised explanation are grouped together at the end, which makes it harder to connect each explanation to the relevant input line. Please restructure the explanation so that details immediately follows the input line they refer to.

Example
* (Both Part 1 and Part 2) Please change "color" to "colour" for consistency.

Constraints
* Please add the constraints on k, x, y and c.

* Please mention that all checkpoints are on empty (<const>.</const>) tiles only. (I assume they never overlap with V or H tiles?)

* Am I correct in assuming that every case in this part contains at least one H, V or X (otherwise, the simplest cases in Part 2 should be moved to Part 1)? If so, please add that as a constraint.

Thanks.

Current differences from part 2:
Test cases will be less sparse.
3 new tiles: Blockers (unusable tiles), directional tiles (can only be used in the direction of the tile) and checkpoints (tile must be included in a certain colours path)

These 3 new tiles should reduce the search space whereas in part 2 the player needs to  do it themselves.

Any additional thoughts or ideas are welcome üôÇ

Updated both versions.

Input:
* Updated to integers for 0-9 (Will be adding a grey for 0). I need to see how much the new tiles shorten the execution time. If it's drastically different I will probably have this version be a-? for additional colours and make bigger tests - Will have to see and I will update accordingly.

Constraints:
* Correct, checkpoints are for empty tiles only.
* Yeah, every case will have at least 1 special tile - Added to contraints.

Thanks, as always.

edit: Updated this version to be 0-9 and a-e for the colour identifier.

I've not looked properly yet, I will do in a little bit, but they seem to be fine to me? Could you provide a photo example?

For "Small 3 Validator":
edit: removed validator

There is no 'e' or 'X' and the flag and debug info match to 'c' and 'b' for me. But as I said, I will take a proper look later.

Can I ask how different your code for part 1 and part 2 is?

Specifically regarding optimization and the Large tests? Do you still have your optimizations from part 2 in your part 1 solution? If so, does removing it cause any issues with any of the cases? Additonally, if any optimizations are used, are they simple enough to fit in the medium category?
Ah well found... I will get a fix sorted as soon as possible. Thanks!
Hopefully should be fixed, let me know I've broken anything else üôÉ

My code for part 1 "is more complicated" than my code for part 2 because I solved part 2 first and did just re-use it to solve part 1 but I had to handle all the extra restrictions that are present in part 1.

My "optimization" for part 2 is that I don't try to fill the whole map, I'm only trying to connect all the colors which is way more easier. When I found a solution then I try to add all the 'unused' positions to an existing path and when I can't do it (I have an odd amount of position left for example) I just try with the next solution that connects all the colors. That way nothing takes more than 5ms.

For part 1 I think that a 'brute force' approach would work, you generate all the possible paths for all the colors (even on the large maps it doesn't look like it would go crazy), you place all the ones with only one possibility and then use backtracking for the rest. That would fit in the medium category.
Timinator has mentioned that the brute force approach fails for the large tests. I will be altering the cases to include more special tiles to hopefully allow the brute force to work.
Large 1 was updated slightly to include more checkpoints, just want to check you're happy with it.
It looks good to me, the number of possible paths is pretty limited.

I've found the issue, the default code to read the input was wrong, I've updated things and now I'm getting the proper values, it was using '%d' which is just for integers but now colors can also be letters.
By restoring to default code I'm now getting the right stuff directly, I'm assuming it's because I started before you made the last changes.
In Medium 1 Validator (Validator) position 4;5 is at the same time a position for the color e and a checkpoint for the color e
Thanks, I have fixed it but have not uploaded the changes yet. Once I update the checkpoints assets, I will be uploading the fix. (now updated)
This version has had some visual updates and test case rehaul since you last commented. Just want to check if you're happy with the new additions, if you find any issues please let me know üòÉ

I've found a bug in my code with the new cases.
I like the changes, everything seems to be working fine for me.

Constraints
* Constraint 5: Please change to the following:
<var>c</var> is a digit (<const>0</const>-<const>9</const>) or one of <const>a</const>-<const>e</const>.

* Please swap the order of the last two constraints.

* (Both Part 1 and Part 2) Please move the constraints on response time and turn limit to the end. With the longer list of constraints now, it feels more logical to group the other constraints together.

Cases
* #12 Medium 1 Validator: The checkpoint at (4, 5) overlaps with the endpoint of colour "e" there, but checkpoints should be on empty tiles only.

Viewer
* At first glance, I thought the starting animation showed a success even though some tiles weren't used. On closer inspection, I realised the bottom middle two tiles were blockers. The blockers (currently black) don't stand out enough against the dark blue usable tiles. Could the colours be adjusted, or blockers made more visually distinct in some way?

* Similar visibility issues occur with the black circles and the black directional tiles; they're also difficult to see.

* Are you planning to adjust the appearance of checkpoint tiles?

Thanks.

Done all but the checkpoints. 

I personally have no issue with with black blockers or the black colour tiles - But I have no issue changing it to be a light grey and the blockers: https://imgur.com/a/H4raoFM

Yeah the checkpoints don't really work when zoomed out with the larger grids - My current plan for them is making the flags larger and adding a border of the checkpoint colour.

Constraints
* Please split the third last constraint into two separate ones.

* Upper limits to be updated.

Example
* Pending.

Viewer
* When the error message "Same tile or not straight line provided" appears, the corresponding tiles aren't always highlighted in red. For example, I added the following lines of code (executed one per run) after the input-reading section for the "Medium 2" (test) case:

print("1 0 2 1 e")
print("1 0 3 2 e")
print("1 0 2 2 e")
print("1 0 2 8 e")

Highlighting works correctly for the first three lines, but for the last line, only one tile is highlighted in red.

* I haven't tested if the same bug affects Part 2.

* The red-cross blockers look clear on small grids, but harder to see on larger grids. Similarly, the directional tiles and the flagpoles of the checkpoint flags are difficult to distinguish. All black elements should be recoloured as light grey, as you suggested, to improve contrast against the dark blue background.

* I completely agree with your plan to make the checkpoint flags larger.

Thanks.

Fixed constraint - Forget to add a
after rearranging Fixed viewer issue - Seems the issue is when the id is above 127 - So it shouldn't affect part 2 but I've added the fix to that one too. I'll take a look at the visuals once I finish the test cases. Thanks ^^
What's the latest status of the contribution?
Not made any progress from where it is currently but will be updating again soon!

Could I get your thoughts on the updated tiles? (I've only done colour 1 checkpoint as I want to get it right before updating the rest). You can use the preview or #36 for the two opposite sizes which include colour 1, blockers and directional tiles.

Blockers: Good

Directional tiles: Good

Checkpoints: The square outline looks good, but could you consider removing the flagpole? Right now, only part of it is visible to me, and it looks like stray pixels.

By the way, there's an extra trailing newline in the input for the "Small 5" test (it probably doesn't affect anything though).

Thanks.

Yeah I've removed the flag, I left it in as it looks nice in the smaller grids but I agree doesn't really work with the larger grids.

Removed the trailing newline, thanks.

I keep getting an error when trying to upload, so I will try upload again later.
ok

Uploaded the updated version with an updated example/constraints section.

I think we're finally getting close to part 1 and part 2 being done üôè

Yay, it's exciting to see everything coming together! Comments from my end:

Example (Part 1 only)
* Please correct the typo: veritcally.

Output per turn
* (Part 2) Please add "space-separated" before "integers".

* (Part 1) Please change "integers" to "space-separated items" (or use another word for "items", e.g. "elements"), and then add "(integer)" after "tile" (4 times), and "(integer/character)" after "identifier".

Cases (Part 1 only)
* These cases violate a constraint as one of the checkpoints isn't on an empty tile:
  ‚Ä¢ Simple Vertical (test)
  ‚Ä¢ Medium 3 (test)

Referee (Part 1 & Part 2)
* In the error message "One or both of the inputs is out of bounds", please change "both" to "more" and "is" to "are" (or possibly "were", see next comment).

* Similarly, for the error message "One or more of the inputs was invalid:", consider updating "was" to "were". Also, you may not need to list the first invalid input, similar to how it's handled in the out-of-bound error message.

* I got an error if I included a leading space in the output, but not if I included a trailing space.

* One of the error triggers/messages might never occur, so you could remove it if you want:
  ‚Ä¢ You did not send a single input.

Viewer (Part 2 only)
* Please use another colour (e.g. dark grey) instead of black for colour identifier 8.

Thanks.

I just noticed another tense inconsistency in this error message (applicable to both Part 1 and Part 2): "All or part of the connection is already made."

Should "is" be "was" to be consistent with the other error messages? It's a minor issue, so feel free to update it if needed and if you've got other changes to make as well (better go through other error messages again too); otherwise, we can leave it as is.

I don't have any other comments for now. Let's wait for @Timinator's more detailed review of the cases. It might also be worth replying to @cedricdd's comment above to invite them to review as well.

Finally, consider replying to your own comment at the top to share the latest progress update.
Agreed, updated the error messages with a couple of changes (adding a word here or there).
Just in case you missed it, Timinator sent you a message on the forum.
